timeline.bodyText: At some point we should also add in read locking, so that it won't try to read while a write is being performed. I've created a followup ticket for doing this with the premis logger: https://jira.lib.unc.edu/browse/BXC-2722

timeline.bodyText:
Good work on this test. Do you know if it fails without the new pid locking code? It can sometimes be hard to trigger concurrency cases with a small number of requests.
It might be good to check the premis log after all the threads have completed to verify that all the expected events are present at once, just to make sure we end up with a merger of the two change sets at the end.
Its too bad we're using a mock binary transfer session in all these tests, so we aren't getting a test of currency in the write code, but judging by the comment on the mock we're probably stuck with it.

timeline.bodyText:
i'm not sure this is showing that the read waited for the write, since we aren't verifying the read hasn't completed before the write
I think you would need to start the read and write threads at the same time, so set up threads in advance and then writeThread.start(); immediately followed by readThread.start();. You'd want to show that the read thread had not completed yet with premisNotes.size() == 0 before the writeThread.join();, and then that the event was present after.
In order to get the timing to work out reliably, in the writeThread you could do:

get a write lock for the object
start the writeEvents operation
sleep for 25ms
release the write lock
